# Intro to Crypto 3

For this challenge we are provided with three RSA public keys and a message encrypted using each of those keys.

Let's dump the public keys:

```sh
$ openssl rsa -pubin -in german_government.pem -text -noout
RSA Public-Key: (2047 bit)
Modulus:
    69:e5:e5:db:6a:80:a3:2c:59:ec:1e:c6:37:10:f4:
    88:64:07:ee:00:07:a1:05:0b:22:17:8d:5a:e8:88:
    65:d8:61:b6:63:71:a9:31:20:d5:81:ba:70:1b:c1:
    22:1c:f2:b4:a0:e3:f3:ff:15:f7:9d:fe:66:d0:f7:
    a7:95:e9:b0:83:65:0f:38:2f:a5:f7:e5:b4:d8:fd:
    7a:85:42:3d:eb:82:63:f5:95:70:1b:9e:86:3e:3b:
    69:8d:3e:d1:62:9b:93:94:58:0a:b5:0c:51:1c:9a:
    9c:05:9f:9b:7c:3f:02:bd:ec:1f:be:4f:a9:b1:3a:

    37:6a:5b:bd:69:3f:27:56:18:d8:c0:90:0e:b4:f4:

    2c:33:a4:30:67:07:70:ab:f2:4d:ae:ea:2f:27:6f:
    67
Exponent: 3 (0x3)

    df:32:93:c8:35:5b:3c:db:f3:7b:26:db:83:8d:20:
    46:aa:18:62:88:51:df:c6:88:3e:17:36:c0:ef:ab:
    a3
Exponent: 3 (0x3)
```

All of them use the same small public exponent 3! That means we can apply HÃ¥stad's broadcast attack to decrypt the message:

```py
from binascii import unhexlify
import gmpy

e = 3

n1 = 
n2 = 
n3 = 

c1 = 
c2 = 
c3 = 

N = n1 * n2 * n3
N1 = N // n1
N2 = N // n2
N3 = N // n3
assert(N1 * n1 == N)
assert(N2 * n2 == N)
assert(N3 * n3 == N)

u1 = gmpy.invert(N1, n1)
u2 = gmpy.invert(N2, n2)
u3 = gmpy.invert(N3, n3)

M = (c1 * u1 * N1 + c2 * u2 * N2 + c3 * u3 * N3) % N

m = gmpy.root(M, e)[0]

print(unhexlify(hex(m)[2:]))
```

The flag is: `CSCG{ch1nes3_g0vernm3nt_h4s_n0_pr0blem_w1th_c0ron4}`
